lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's a sophisticated React app without some beautiful styling?

Let's dive into how to use CSS to style our single-page applications.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When creating a React app, we can use a normal CSS file. Within that file, we can define any CSS rule that we want.

Define a rule that targets the body element.

Make sure to pick body, followed by {, and finally }.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To apply the CSS, we need to import the CSS file. We do this directly in a component.

Import the file to apply the CSS.

Make sure to pick import, followed by "./App.css", and finally ;.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use CSS rules to target an element with a certain ID, as we would when using CSS with HTML.

To make the CSS rule in the App.css file work, set the attribute id to box.

Make sure to pick id, followed by =, and finally "box".

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now, let's use a rule to target elements with a particular class attached.

Create a rule that targets elements with the class box.

Make sure to pick . followed by box and then {, }.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In JSX, we use the keyword className to apply a class to an element, similar to the class attribute in HTML.

Use className to set a CSS class on an element in JSX, just like the class attribute in HTML.

Make sure to pick className, followed by =, and finally "box".

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
We need to link the stylesheet index.css in the HTML because the bundler needs this to load our CSS files properly.

We need to always reference an index.css file but should not actually use a file with this name.

Make sure to pick link, followed by rel="stylesheet", and finally href="./index.css".

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When coding React, we need a bundler, a tool that combines all our files to make the app work.

The bundler requires the link to an index.css file. However, we don't need to create the file. The bundler does that for us.

Make sure to pick ./, followed by index.css.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a CSS rule for the class defined in the App component.

Make sure to type box.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, what is the equivalent attribute we use instead of class in HTML for applying styles?

classNameclassname

Make sure to pick className.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Style a button by setting the correct class.

Make sure to pick className.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the correct way to import a CSS file into a React component?

import "./App.css"import { "./App.css" }

import "./App.css".

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import the App.css file to add the animation to the App component.

Make sure to type import.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we import a CSS file in one of our files, the styling will be applied to everything that's rendered.

Implement the App.css file in the App.jsx file to see the CSS applied to all components.

Make sure to pick import, followed by "./App.css", and finally ;.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
It doesn't matter which component loads the CSS.

Implement the App.css file in the Header.jsx file to see the CSS applied to all components.

Make sure to type import.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To keep the CSS nicely separated, it's best practice to include only a few global styles, such as general styles, in the App.css file.

To avoid styling specific components in the App.css file, declare only one rule to target the body.

Make sure to pick body, followed by {, and finally }.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
It's best to create a CSS file for each component and keep styles scoped to that component.

Implement the ArticlePreview.css file in the ArticlePreview.jsx file to use a CSS file for this specific component.

Make sure to pick import, followed by "./ArticlePreview.css", and finally ;.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Once we have a dedicated CSS file for a component, we can use this file to define CSS that is specific for this class.

Implement two rules targeting the articlePreviewWrapper class used in the ArticlePreview component.

Make sure to pick . followed by articlePreviewWrapper and then ., articlePreviewWrapper.

lessons.title: s
lessons.interactiveContent:
However, if you import a CSS file in a specific component, the CSS will still be applied globally.

Create a rule that targets all div elements and see how the div in the App component will be targeted.

Make sure to pick div, followed by {, and finally }.

lessons.title: s - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To avoid unwanted side effects in other parts of the app, it's best to use component-specific classes and target those.

Set the class articlePreviewWrapper to the div in the ArticlePreview class to be able to target it specifically in the CSS file.

Make sure to pick className, followed by =, and finally "articlePreviewWrapper".

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a Footer component and apply unique CSS styles just to this component by importing the correct CSS file.

Make sure to pick import, followed by "./Footer.css".

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be the result of importing a CSS file in one of the components?

The styles will be applied globally, affecting all relevant elements across the applicationThe styles will apply only to the component where it is imported

The styles will be applied globally, affecting all relevant elements across the application.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use a class that is specific to the Profile component.

Make sure to pick className, followed by =, and finally "profileContainer".

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
If you have multiple CSS files in your React project, which scenario best practices should you follow?

Keep styles scoped to specific components by using CSS files for each componentInclude all specific component styles in a single global CSS file

Keep styles scoped to specific components by using CSS files for each component.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is a best practice for managing CSS in a React application?

Create a CSS file for each component and import it as neededCombine all CSS into a single file regardless of the project size

Create a CSS file for each component and import it as needed.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, we can use the passed properties to adapt a generic component to our liking.

Like changing the size of a box.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we define a property and pass different values to it, we can use that property to customize the generic component later.

Make sure to pick size, followed by size, and finally size.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
A neat way to adapt the design to our liking is to create classes for our elements based on the passed properties.

Use the passed property size in the conditional statement to check which size was passed.

Make sure to pick props followed by .size and then props, .size, props, .size.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can then adapt the value of the string of the boxClass variable.

The boxClass variable holds either only the standard box class or box and a more specific size class.

Make sure to pick boxClass followed by boxClass and then boxClass, boxClass, boxClass.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use a shorter version using template literals and string interpolation.

Use string interpolation to construct the individual classes box--small, box--medium, and box--large.

Make sure to pick props, followed by ., and finally size.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Another great way to create CSS classes on the fly is to use state variables.

Use string interpolation to construct the individual classes based on the state variable mode.

Make sure to pick mode, followed by mode, and finally mode.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the passed property size to create a class on the fly.

Make sure to type size.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does <Text size="medium" /> render?

Text with a medium font sizeText with a small font sizeText with a large font size

Text with a medium font size.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use props to change the background color of different divs.

Make sure to type color.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the right CSS rules to change text alignment based on passed props.

Make sure to pick . followed by text-align-left and then ., text-align-center, ., text-align-right.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to create the classes that display the content in a list or grid. Check App.css for a hint of how the class should look.

Make sure to pick layout followed by - and then $, {, layout, }.
